title: 110_hr1679
content: The Act is titled the "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" and states its policy. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to deny Cuba resources that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, and Cuba's submerged lands. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to prevent the prolongation of the dictatorship in Cuba and deter foreign investments in the country's petroleum resources. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended to exclude aliens who contribute to Cuba's development of petroleum resources off its coast. The Secretary of State and Homeland Security will deny visas and exclude aliens who invest over $1,000,000 in entities enhancing Cuba's government. The Government of Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources off its coast is restricted, and the Secretary of State can waive this restriction for critical medical reasons or litigation purposes. The Government of Cuba can develop petroleum resources off its coast with restrictions, and the Secretary of State can waive these restrictions for critical medical reasons or litigation purposes. Definitions include the Cuban Communist Party as an agent and instrumentality, and investment refers to any involvement in petroleum resources. Investment refers to activities related to developing petroleum resources off Cuba's coast through agreements with the Cuban government or nongovernmental entities since January 10, 2005. Investment in developing petroleum resources off Cuba's coast can involve various activities such as purchasing ownership shares, entering contracts for supervision or guarantee of performance, participating in royalties or profits, and buying/selling goods or services. The amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the US for purchasing goods, services, or technology related to petroleum resources. The amendment imposes sanctions and prohibits the facilitation of Cuba's petroleum resources development. The President may impose sanctions on individuals who have made investments over $1,000,000 contributing to Cuba's petroleum development or trafficked in confiscated US property after January 10, 2005. The President can impose sanctions on individuals who have invested over $1,000,000 in Cuba's petroleum development or trafficked in confiscated US property after January 10, 2005. Sanctions may include prohibiting loans, guarantees, and exports to sanctioned persons. Sanctions may be imposed on individuals under various acts requiring US Government approval for export of goods or services. Financial institutions may face prohibitions, such as being designated as a primary dealer. Financial institutions may face sanctions, including being prohibited from serving as a primary dealer in US Government debt instruments or as a repository for government funds. Sanctions may include prohibiting financial institutions from serving as a repository for US Government funds or procuring goods or services from sanctioned individuals. Sanctions imposed will terminate if the President determines. The President can terminate sanctions if requirements of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act are met. US persons are prohibited from aiding Cuba in developing petroleum resources. The Secretary of State must submit reports within 180 days. The Secretary of State must submit reports every 180 days regarding investments in Cuba that enhance the government's abilities. The Secretary of State must submit reports every 180 days regarding investments in Cuba that enhance the government's abilities, including information on investments in petroleum resources and sanctions imposed on investments related to trafficking in confiscated US property. The Secretary of State must provide information on investments in Cuba that enhance the government's abilities, including details on investments in petroleum resources and sanctions imposed on investments related to trafficking in confiscated US property. Additionally, assessments of the environmental impacts of Cuba's petroleum development must be submitted annually. The Secretary of State, in consultation with relevant agencies, must submit a report to congressional committees assessing the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum development on submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment. The Secretary of State will use environmental impact statements as a model for assessing the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum development on submerged lands and Florida's marine environment. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, terms like "appropriate congressional committees", "confiscated", "person", "property", and "traffics" are defined as per the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996. Additionally, terms like "develop", "investment", and "petroleum resources" are defined as per section 402(c) of the same Act. The terms "agent" and "instrumentality" are also defined within the context of this Act. The terms "agent" and "instrumentality" within this Act now include the Cuban Communist Party.
